repnme.cdata!:
Trinidad-Tobago - Water Sector
            Institutional Strengthening Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The audit accords with the
            Implementation Completion Report ratings of unsatisfactory
            project outcome, unlikely sustainability, and negligible
            institutional development impacts. The overall disappointing
            performance mainly reflects over-ambitious objectives for
            such a short implementation period, and a government change
            at the outset, which exposed incomplete commitment to the
            project strategy, exacerbating design, and preparation
            shortfalls. The experience of this project confirms a number
            of lessons: 1) in responding to emergencies, assistance in a
            conventional project format should be limited to the
            immediate emergency, while a series of Adjustable Program
            Loans, may be a better instrument for longer term needs; 2)
            a thorough political risk analysis, and ensured broad
            political support - e.g., privatization, and utility tariff
            modification - is essential whenever government, or policy
            changes could occur; 3) contract management should consider,
            and avoid potential conflicts of interest, by excluding
            contractors who bid on the preparation of privatization
            arrangements from bidding on supply, and construction
            contracts, or the privatization itself; and, carefully
            foster incentives and/or penalties in management contracts,
            to ensure proper contractor performance; and, 4) greater
            consistency is needed in project documents, so as to improve
            understanding, and agreement in the statement of objectives,
            and project description.

2317994.trustfund: TF022722-PHRD-ECONOMIC RECOVERY PROJECT,TF022985-SIDA CTF FOR ENVIRONMENT-MARINE ENVIRON.

repnme.cdata!:
Trinidad and Tobago - Water Sector
            Institutional Strengthening Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The project is rated unsatisfactory, and
            sustainability is unlikely for the short term, and,
            uncertain for the medium term. The Bank performance was
            inadequate in the design for private participation
            inclusion, was not appropriate on decisions regarding issues
            on performance indicators, and, supervision was deficient on
            several fronts, namely, lack of financial covenants'
            monitoring, weakness towards achieving appraisal indicators,
            and, lack of substantive auditing action. Likewise, the
            Borrower's performance was mostly unsatisfactory,
            accounting for both implementation, and counterpart funding
            delays. Lessons indicate that private participation in
            infrastructure would better succeed under an open process
            design, with an approach towards public sharing of
            contracts, preventing governmental mistrust, offering
            instead a participatory strategy, i.e., broader dialogue,
            ownership, and transparency. Management contracts should
            encompass a framework for incentives, to prevent negative
            monitoring impacts, in the absence of performance
            indicators. Furthermore, contracts need to be comprehensive,
            and self-contained, allowing the management contractor full
            autonomy, and the resources to meet the performance
            indicators. Consequently, governments need to accept full
            responsibility for the development of performance
            indicators, and the underlying data.

18225114.majtheme: Environment and natural resource management,Social protection and risk management

repnme.cdata!:
Trinidad and Tobago - Water Sector
            Institutional Strengthening Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Water Sector
            Institutional Strengthening Project are to: a) strengthen
            water resources management; b) support introduction of
            private sector management in the Water and Sewerage
            Authority (WASA); and c) prepare a drainage and flood
            control project. The project will:: i) finance short- and
            medium-term technical assistance to the Ministry of Works
            and Transport and the Ministry of Public Utilities in
            strengthening the institutions involved in management of the
            country's water resources; ii) develop a national water
            resources management strategy; iii) provide funding for
            consultant services and working capital needed by the Water
            and Sewerage Authority (WASA) during the transition of its
            water supply services operation to private sector
            management, and iv) help prepare a program of short-term
            rehabilitation and maintenance enhancement and a medium-term
            program of investment in flood control and drainage infrastructure.
